docs.title: OpenSpot API
docs.text:
Corporate perks, without the stuffy corporate office.

The OpenSpot API lets developers access real-time data for coworking and coliving paces around the world. You can retrieve details like location, pricing, capacity, and current availability to help users find and book flexible workspaces anywhere. Designed for seamless integration, OpenSpot makes it easy to power the future of remote work and living.

This mock API behaves like a real backend service, allowing you to test endpoints, build your frontend, and practice making HTTP requests—even though the real OpenSpot backend does not exist yet.

docs.title: Helpful resources
docs.text:
• Getting Started Learn how to install Node.js, set up the JSON Server, and run your first API request.

  • Tutorials Step-by-step guides that walk you through common tasks like adding a new space or checking availability.

  • API Reference Guide A complete list of resources and endpoints, ideal for quick lookup or advanced users.

docs.title: Who is this API for?
docs.text:
The OpenSpot API is built for developers who want to integrate coliving and coworking data into their applications. Whether you're building:

  • A booking platform for coliving spaces

  • A tool to support remote teams or satellite offices

  • A workspace discovery app for freelancers or small business owners

OpenSpot gives you structured, queryable access to global workspace data.

docs.title: Common use cases
docs.text:
• You're starting your small business, and need to separate your living space from your working space as you grow.

  • Your company wants to build an app that helps remote employees find coworking locations for temporary satellite offices.

docs.title: Support
docs.text: If you have any questions, or if you need assistance, feel free to contact our Support Team.

docs.title: Related pages
docs.text:
• Spaces resource

  • Availability resource

docs.title: API Reference Guide
docs.text:
This section provides a high-level reference for all endpoints in the OpenSpot API mock server. Each resource includes its own detailed page with request and response examples.

The OpenSpot API models coworking and coliving data using JSON Server. It exposes two primary resources:

  • spaces – coworking and coliving locations
  • availability – date-based availability for each space

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text:
All endpoints are served from the following base URL when running JSON Server locally:

http://localhost:3000

docs.title: HTTP Requests
docs.text:
Each resource supports standard CRUD-style operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete) via HTTP methods such as GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE.

Method Description Example GET Retrieve one or more resource objects. GET /spaces, GET spaces/1 POST Create a new resource object. POST /spaces PUT Replace an existing resource object completely. PUT /spaces/1 PATCH Partially update an existing resource object. PATCH /availability/2 DELETE Delete an existing resource object. DELETE /spaces/1

docs.title: Availability Resource Overview
docs.text: The availability resource represents the spots available for coliving and coworking spaces in the OpenSpot API. Each availability object contains information about its available spots and the date.

docs.title: Resource Structure
docs.text:
A spaces resource includes the following properties:

Property Type Description id integer Unique identifier for the availability record (auto-generated) spaceId integer Reference to the associated space ID availableSpots integer Number of spots currently available date string Date of availability in "YYYY-MM-DD" format

docs.title: Available Operations
docs.text:
The availability resource supports the following operations:

  • Retrieve all availability records or filter by space ID or date
  • Create new availability records
  • Update existing availability records (partial or full)
  • Delete availability records

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Check availability for a specific space on a given date
  • Update available spots when bookings are made or cancelled
  • Add availability records for new dates or spaces
  • Remove outdated availability records
  • Track real-time capacity across all spaces

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text: http://localhost:3000/availability

docs.title: DELETE /availability - Delete Availability
docs.text: Use the DELETE method to remove an existing availability resource.

docs.title: Permanently delete a availability
docs.text: Permanently delete the availability information for a coliving or coworking space from the database.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: DELETE /availability/{id}

docs.title: Request body
docs.text: None.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description id number Yes The unique identifier of the availability to delete

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Availability deleted successfully success - empty object 404 Availability not found error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text: curl -X DELETE http://localhost:3000/availability/3

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to DELETE
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/availability/3
  3. Ensure Body is set to none.

  4. Click Send

docs.title: Example response
docs.text: {}

docs.title: GET /availability - Retrieve Availability
docs.text: Use the GET method to access /availability resource data.

docs.title: Retrieve all availability records
docs.text: Retrieve all availability records for coliving and coworking spaces.

docs.title: Request body
docs.text: None

docs.title: Responses

docs.title: cURL
docs.text: curl GET http://localhost:3000/availability

docs.text:
1. Set method to GET
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/availability
  3. Click Send

[

    "id": 1,
    "spaceId": 1,
    "availableSpots": 3,
    "date": "2025-12-10"

    "id": 2,
    "spaceId": 2,
    "availableSpots": 10,
    "date": "2025-12-10"
  },
  {
    "id": 3,
    "spaceId": 3,
    "availableSpots": 5,
    "date": "2025-12-10"
  },
  {
    "id": 4,
    "spaceId": 4,
    "availableSpots": 4,
    "date": "2025-12-10"

]

  "spaceId": 1,

docs.title: Retrieve availability by space ID
docs.text: Retrieve availability records for a specific space.

docs.title: Endpoint

docs.title: Request body

docs.title: Parameters

docs.title: Responses

docs.text: curl GET http://localhost:3000/availability?spaceId=1

    "id": 1,

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 List of availability records for the date availability[] 404 No availability records found error object

    "id": 2,

  },

    "id": 3,
    "spaceId": 3,

docs.title: PATCH /availability - Update Availability
docs.text: Use the PATCH method to partially update an existing availability resource.

docs.title: Update an availability record
docs.text: Partially update an availability record. Only the fields provided in the request body will be updated.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: PATCH /availability/{id}

docs.title: Request body
docs.text:
Include only the fields you want to update. All fields are optional.

{
  "spaceId": number,
  "availableSpots": number,
  "date": "string"
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "availableSpots": 5
}

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description id number Yes The unique identifier of the availability record to modify.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Availability record updated successfully availability object 404 Availability record not found error object 400 Bad request - invalid data error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
curl -X PATCH http://localhost:3000/availability/1 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "availableSpots": 5
  }'

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to PATCH
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/availability/1
  3. Go to Body tab
  4. Select raw and choose JSON from dropdown

  5. Paste the request body JSON (only fields to update):

    {
"availableSpots": 5
}

  6. Click Send

docs.title: Example response
docs.text:
{
  "id": 1,
  "spaceId": 1,
  "availableSpots": 5,
  "date": "2025-12-10"
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Only the fields included in the request body will be updated
  • All other fields remain unchanged
  • The id field cannot be modified
  • Date must be in "YYYY-MM-DD" format if updating
  • spaceId must reference an existing space if updating

docs.title: PATCH vs PUT
docs.text: Method Use Case Example PATCH Update specific fields only Change only available spots PUT Replace entire resource Update all fields at once

docs.title: POST /availability - Create Availability Record
docs.text: Use the POST method to add a new /availability resource.

docs.title: Create an availability record
docs.text: Create a new availability record for a coliving or coworking space.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: POST /availability

docs.title: Request body
docs.text:
{
  "spaceId": number,
  "availableSpots": number,
  "date": "string"
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "spaceId": 1,
  "availableSpots": 7,
  "date": "2025-12-11"
}

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: None.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 201 Availability record created successfully availability object 404 Resource not found error object 400 Bad request - invalid data error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/availability \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "spaceId": 1,
    "availableSpots": 7,
    "date": "2025-12-11"
  }'

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to POST
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/availability
  3. Go to Body tab
  4. Select raw and choose JSON from dropdown

  5. Paste the request body JSON:

        {
    "spaceId": 1,
    "availableSpots": 7,
    "date": "2025-12-11"
    }

  6. Click Send

docs.title: Example response
docs.text:
{
  "id": 5,
  "spaceId": 1,
  "availableSpots": 7,
  "date": "2025-12-11"
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• The id field is automatically generated by json-server
  • All fields except id should be included in the request body
  • Date must be in "YYYY-MM-DD" format
  • spaceId must reference an existing space
  • availableSpots should not exceed the space's capacity

docs.title: PUT /availability - Replace Availability
docs.text: Use the PUT method to completely replace an existing availability resource.

docs.title: Replace an availability record
docs.text: Replace an entire availability record. All fields must be provided in the request body.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: PUT /availability/{id}

docs.title: Request body
docs.text:
All fields (except id) must be included in the request body to replace the entire resource.

{
  "spaceId": number,
  "availableSpots": number,
  "date": "string"
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "spaceId": 1,
  "availableSpots": 8,
  "date": "2025-12-15"
}
Parameter Type Required Description id number Yes The unique identifier of the availability record to modify.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Availability record replaced successfully availability object 404 Availability record not found error object 400 Bad request - invalid or missing data error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
curl -X PUT http://localhost:3000/availability/1 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "spaceId": 1,
    "availableSpots": 8,
    "date": "2025-12-15"
  }'

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to PUT
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/availability/1
  3. Go to Body tab
  4. Select raw and choose JSON from dropdown

  5. Paste the complete request body JSON:

        {
    "spaceId": 1,
    "availableSpots": 8,
    "date": "2025-12-15"
    }

  6. Click Send

docs.title: Example Response
docs.text:
{
  "id": 1,
  "spaceId": 1,
  "availableSpots": 8,
  "date": "2025-12-15"
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• PUT replaces the entire resource, so all fields must be provided
  • Missing fields will be removed from the record
  • The id field cannot be modified and should not be included in the request body
  • spaceId must reference an existing space

docs.title: PUT vs PATCH
docs.text: Method Use Case Example PATCH Update specific fields only Change only available spots PUT Replace entire resource Update all fields at once

docs.title: DELETE /spaces - Delete a Space

docs.title: Retrieve a space by ID
docs.text: Retrieve a single coliving and coworking space by ID.

docs.text:

  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/spaces/2

docs.title: Example response
docs.text:
{
    "id": 2,
    "name": "WorkHub Central",
    "location": "Austin, USA",
    "pricePerHour": 3,
    "capacity": 40,
    "description": "Downtown coworking hub with high-speed Wi-Fi and free coffee."

docs.title: Retrieve spaces by location
docs.text: Retrieve coliving and coworking spaces by location.

docs.title: Endpoint exact match
docs.text: GET /spaces?location=<CityName>,<CountryName>

docs.title: Endpoint partial match
docs.text: GET /spaces?location_like=<PartialLocation>

docs.title: Request body
docs.text: None

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
Parameter Type Required Description location string Yes Exact location match. Format: "City, Country" (e.g., "Lisbon, Portugal") location_like string No* Partial location match. Searches for any location containing the string (e.g., "Lisbon" or "Portugal")

[!NOTE] *location_like is not required for this query, but offers a bit more flexibility.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 List of spaces matching location spaces[] 404 No matching spaces found error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text: curl GET http://localhost:3000/spaces?location="Lisbon, Portugal"

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to GET
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/spaces/2
  3. Click Send

docs.title: Example Response
docs.text:
{
    "id": 2,
    "name": "WorkHub Central",
    "location": "Austin, USA",
    "pricePerHour": 3,
    "capacity": 40,
    "description": "Downtown coworking hub with high-speed Wi-Fi and free coffee."
}

docs.title: PATCH /spaces - Update a Space
docs.text: Use the PATCH method to partially update an existing space resource.

docs.title: Update a space
docs.text: Partially update a coliving or coworking space. Only the fields provided in the request body will be updated.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: PATCH /spaces/{id}

docs.title: Request body
docs.text:
Include only the fields you want to update. All fields are optional.

{
  "name": "string",
  "location": "string",
  "pricePerHour": number,
  "capacity": number,
  "description": "string"
}

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "pricePerHour": 8,
  "capacity": 18
}

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Description id number Yes The unique identifier of the space to modify.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Space updated successfully spaces object 404 Space not found error object 400 Bad request - invalid data error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
curl -X PATCH http://localhost:3000/spaces/2 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "pricePerHour": 8
  }'

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to PATCH
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/spaces/2
  3. Go to Body tab
  4. Select raw and choose JSON from dropdown

  5. Paste the request body JSON (only fields to update):

    {
"pricePerHour": 8
}

  6. Click Send

docs.title: Example response
docs.text:
{
  "id": 2,
  "name": "WorkHub Central",
  "location": "Austin, USA",
  "pricePerHour": 8,
  "capacity": 40,
  "description": "Downtown coworking hub with high-speed Wi-Fi and free coffee." 
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• Only the fields included in the request body will be updated
  • All other fields remain unchanged
  • The id field cannot be modified

docs.title: PATCH vs PUT
docs.text: Method Use Case Example PATCH Update specific fields only Change only price PUT Replace entire resource Update all fields at once

docs.title: PUT /spaces - Replace a Space
docs.text: Use the PUT method to completely replace an existing space resource.

docs.text: Replace an entire coliving or coworking space. All fields must be provided in the request body.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: PUT /spaces/{id}

docs.title: Request body
docs.text:
All fields (except id) must be included in the request body to replace the entire resource.

{
  "name": "string",
  "location": "string",
  "pricePerHour": number,
  "capacity": number,
  "description": "string"
}

docs.title: Example

}
Parameter Type Required Description id number Yes The unique identifier of the space to modify.

docs.title: Responses
docs.text: HTTP Code Description Schema 200 Space replaced successfully spaces object 404 Space not found error object 400 Bad request * invalid or missing data error object

docs.title: cURL
docs.text:
curl -X PUT http://localhost:3000/spaces/3 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{

    "description": "Newly renovated community-driven coliving for digital nomads with ocean views."

docs.title: Postman
docs.text:
1. Set method to PUT
  2. Enter URL: http://localhost:3000/spaces/3
  3. Go to Body tab
  4. Select raw and choose JSON from dropdown

  5. Paste the complete request body JSON:

    {
"name": "The Nest Renovated",
"location": "Lisbon, Portugal",
"pricePerHour": 8,
"capacity": 25,
"description": "Newly renovated community-driven coliving for digital nomads with ocean views."
}

  6. Click Send

docs.title: Example Response
docs.text:
{
  "id": 3,
  "name": "The Nest Renovated",
  "location": "Lisbon, Portugal",
  "pricePerHour": 8,
  "capacity": 25,
  "description": "Newly renovated community-driven coliving for digital nomads with ocean views."
}

docs.title: Notes
docs.text:
• PUT replaces the entire resource, so all fields must be provided
  • Missing fields will be set to null or removed (depending on json-server behavior)
  • The id field cannot be modified and should not be included in the request body

docs.title: PUT vs PATCH
docs.text: Method Use Case Example PATCH Update specific fields only Change only price PUT Replace entire resource Update all fields at once

docs.title: Spaces Resource Overview
docs.text: The spaces resource represents coliving and coworking spaces available in the OpenSpot API. Each space contains information about its location, pricing, capacity, and a description of its amenities.

docs.title: Resource Structure
docs.text:
A spaces resource includes the following properties:

Property Type Description id integer Unique identifier for the space (auto-generated) name string Name of the coliving or coworking space location string Geographic location in "City, Country" format pricePerHour number Hourly rate for the space in USD capacity integer Maximum occupancy of the space description string Detailed description of the space and its features

docs.title: Available Operations
docs.text:
The spaces resource supports the following operations:

  • Retrieve all spaces or filter by ID or location
  • Create new spaces
  • Update existing spaces (partial or full)
  • Delete spaces

docs.title: Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Browse available coworking and coliving spaces
  • Search for spaces by location
  • Add new spaces to the system
  • Update space details such as pricing or capacity
  • Remove spaces that are no longer available

docs.title: Base URL
docs.text: http://localhost:3000/spaces

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
When working with the OpenSpot API locally, you will use Node.js and JSON Server to create a fully functional mock REST API powered by your OpenSpot JSON database file.

This guide will help you to do the following:

  • Install Node.js

  • Install JSON server

  • Download OpenSpot API mock json file

  • Run a simple GET command from the CLI using cURL

docs.title: Installing Node.js
docs.text:
Node.js is a JavaScript runtime that allows you to run JavaScript without the use of a browser.

It also includes npm (Node Package Manager), which is required to install JSON Server.

You'll first want to verify that you have Node.js already installed.

  1. Open a CLI (command line interface) and enter node -v.

If a version number appears, then you already have Node.js installed and you can move on to installing JSON server.

If you do not have it installed, then continue with the following steps:

  1. Visit: https://nodejs.org/en/download

  2. Download the latest LTS for your operating system.

  3. Run the installer and complete the setup.

  4. Verify the install by entering the following command in the CLI:

node -v

docs.title: Installing JSON server
docs.text:
Once you have Node.js installed, you can go ahead and install JSON server. For this documentation, you should use v0.17.4 since the OpenSpot API json file is formatted to work with this version.

  1. From the CLI enter:

npm install -g json-server@0.17.4

  1. After the install is complete, confirm by entering:

json-server --version

You should see 0.17.4

docs.title: Using the OpenSpot API json file
docs.text:
In order to use the OpenSpot API json file, you will need to fork and clone the OpenSpot API repository from Github first.

Once you have completed cloning you can now open the json file with JSON server.

  1. Navigate to the folder where you cloned the OpenSpot API project.

For example: C:\<projectpath>\openspot-api

  1. Right click inside of this folder and select Open in Terminal (Windows 11).

  2. Then run the following command:

json-server --watch openspot-db-source.json --port 3000

This is the output you should see:

  \{^_^}/ hi!

  Loading openspot-db-source.json
  Done

  Resources
  http://localhost:3000/spaces
  http://localhost:3000/availability

  Home
  http://localhost:3000

docs.title: Run a GET request with cURL
docs.text:
1. Open a command line and enter:

    curl http://localhost:3000/spaces

You should now see the list of all the spaces included in the OpenSpot API json file.

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text:
Tutorial: Add a new space

API Reference Guide

docs.title: Tutorial - Add a New Space
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to create a new space in the OpenSpot API JSON mock database. In order to add a new space, you'll need to use the POST HTTP method.

The POST method appends a new space object to the spaces array. This is useful when you need to add a newly available coworking or coliving space.

You can reasonably expect this tutorial to take about 10 minutes or less to complete.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Make sure you have set up your database environment by following the steps in the Set up your server guide.

You will also need to download and use Postman. You can optionally use cURL, however, Postman for POST calls are generally more intuitive. Since you will be entering body information, the formatting is more simple in Postman as opposed to cURL in the CLI.

docs.title: Add a new space
docs.text:
Follow the steps below to create a new space.

  1. Open an instance of Postman and create a new Request by clicking the '+'.

  2. Select POST from the dropdown.

  3. Enter the following URL into the URL field:

    http://localhost:3000/spaces

  4. Select the Body tab and select the raw radio button.

  5. Enter the following body information:

    ```json
{
"name": "Sunset Studio",
"location": "Barcelona, Spain",
"pricePerHour": 6,
"capacity": 15,
"description": "Bright coworking space with Mediterranean views and creative atmosphere."
}
```

  6. Click Send.

You have now successfully added a new space to the OpenSpot API.

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text: POST /spaces

docs.title: Tutorial - Remove a Space
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to remove a space object in the OpenSpot API JSON mock database. In order to remove a space, you'll need to use the DELETE HTTP method.

The DELETE method removes a space object from the spaces array. This is useful when you need remove coworking or coliving space that is off the market or in need of repairs before you list it again.

You can reasonably expect this tutorial to take about 10 minutes or less to complete.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Make sure you have set up your database environment by following the steps in the Set up your server guide.

You will also need to download and use Postman. You can optionally use cURL, however, Postman for POST calls are generally more intuitive.

docs.title: Delete a space
docs.text: Follow the steps below to delete a space.

docs.title: cURL example
docs.text:
1. Open a CLI (command line interface) and enter the following command:

    curl -X DELETE "http://localhost:3000/spaces/2"

  2. Hit Enter to run the command.

  3. To verify the record was delete run the following command:

    curl "http://localhost:3000/spaces"

As you can see from the screenshots above, the space with ID 2, has been removed from the database.

docs.title: Postman example
docs.text:
1. Open an instance of Postman and create a new Request by clicking the '+'.

  2. Select DELETE from the dropdown.

  3. Enter the following URL into the URL field:

    http://localhost:3000/spaces/2

  4. Click SEND.

You have now successfully deleted a space from the OpenSpot API mock database.

Note

When you delete a space, its linked availability record is also deleted. This prevents leftover availability data from remaining in the database. So in this tutorial we deleted "space 2" which also deleted "availability 2" since "availability 2" was associated with the space ID of 2.

    {
    "id": 2,
    "spaceId": 2,
    "availableSpots": 10,
    "date": "2025-12-10"
}

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text: DELETE spaces

docs.title: Tutorial - Find space by location
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to find spaces by their location in the OpenSpot API JSON mock database. In order to find spaces, you'll need to use the GET HTTP method.

The GET method queries the database for all instances of specified properties and returns a spaces array. This is useful when you need to see a full list of coworking or coliving spaces in a particular area.

You can reasonably expect this tutorial to take about 10 minutes or less to complete.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Make sure you have set up your database environment by following the steps in the Set up your server guide.

You will also need to download and use Postman or use cURL from the command line.

docs.title: Find spaces by location
docs.text:
For this tutorial we will be using the _like JSON Server filter operator. This will allow us to filter locations that may only be partial matches. For example, you can use _like in queries similar to GET /spaces?location_like=berlin to find all spaces within Berlin without needing the exact 'City, Country' match.

This is useful when an API may not specify the exact format of the resource's variables. You can think of it as emulating intelligent search that you would typically find when interacting with real APIs.

Follow the steps below to find all instances of spaces by their location.

docs.title: cURL walkthrough
docs.text:
1. Open a CLI (command line interface) and enter the following command:

    curl "http://localhost:3000/spaces?location_like=canada"

  2. Hit Enter to run the command.

docs.title: Postman walkthrough
docs.text:
1. Open an instance of Postman and create a new Request by clicking the '+'.

  2. Select GET from the dropdown.

  3. Enter the following URL into the URL field:

    http://localhost:3000/spaces?location_like=canada

  4. Click Send.

Note

In Postman when you enter the query information, this will open the Params tab and render a table of key-value pairs. You can further narrow filters by entering additional keys and values with this handy GUI table.

You have now successfully found all the spaces filtered by location using a partial match.

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text: GET /spaces

docs.title: Tutorial - Update Availability
docs.text:
In this tutorial, you'll learn how to partially update an availability object in the OpenSpot API JSON mock database. In order to only update a single or subset of properties for a resource instance, you'll need to use the PATCH HTTP method.

The PATCH method modifies specified user-defined properties and updates the availability object. This is useful when you need to update only the available spots left without modifying other properties.

You can reasonably expect this tutorial to take about 10 minutes or less to complete.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
Make sure you have set up your database environment by following the steps in the Set up your server guide.

You will also need to download and use Postman. You can optionally use cURL, however, Postman for POST calls are generally more intuitive. Since you will be entering body information, the formatting is more simple in Postman as opposed to cURL in the CLI.

docs.title: Update availability
docs.text:
1. Open an instance of Postman and create a new Request by clicking the '+'.

  2. Select PATCH from the dropdown.

  3. Enter the following URL into the URL field:

    http://localhost:3000/availability/2

  4. Select the Body tab and select the raw radio button.

  5. Enter the following body information:

    ```json
{
    "availableSpots": 6
}
```

  6. Click Send.

As you can see from the screenshots, "availability record 2" originally showed 10 available spots. After applying the PATCH request, the record updated to 6 available spots without altering the date or IDs.

Note

If you had used the PUT method instead, JSON Server would have replaced the entire object, removing any properties not included in your request (such as the date field).

docs.title: Additional resources
docs.text: PATCH /availability
